Let's be clear, "Safer Internet Day" is everyday.

We are keeping the pressure on @YouTube until they remove dangerous "How To Tie a Noose" videos off the platform. https://t.co/vRCd08vFDx
Excited about this! Hope you‚Äôll join us tonight at 7:05pm.üéô https://t.co/nYDDzsAIpu

It's my sincere hope that people become aware of this problem and join me in this fight. 

Let‚Äôs #TakeThemDown on behalf of all the families across our country who have experienced immeasurable heartbreak‚Äîand to save countless others from experiencing that same grief.

There is precedent for this step‚ÄîYouTube and other platforms have taken down certain so-called ‚Äúconversion therapy‚Äù videos which do severe, demonstrated harm to young LGBTQ+ people. 

As with that issue, this is about protecting our kids. Full stop.

Suicide rates for children 5 to 11 years old are rising dramatically: they have tripled, and 78% of those deaths were by hanging.

It's no secret that the internet can teach children anything, including information that be the difference between life and death.

THREAD: In 2020, I led a letter to @YouTube asking them them to take steps to make sure kids couldn‚Äôt easily access "How To Tie a Noose" videos.

No action was taken.

Today, on #SaferInternetDay, I demand action, and I won't stop fighting until the videos come down. https://t.co/nyaRcbDdui

On #SaferInternetDay, I'm calling on @YouTube to take a simple, commonsense step to prevent adolescent suicide by taking dangerous "How To Tie a Noose" videos down.

If they are making a profit from our children's viewership, they should at least make the platform safer. https://t.co/NywvHhfwuW
